Appearance
From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: cognac

English

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From French Cognac, from Occitan Conhac, from Medieval Latin Comniacum, from the name Cominius, Cominia + Gallo-Roman suffix -acum (from Latin -ācea).

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • Audio (US):(file)

Proper noun

[edit]
English Wikipedia has an article on:
Cognac (commune)
Wikipedia

Cognac

  2. A city and commune of Charente department, region of Nouvelle-Aquitaine, France; famous for cognac brandy.

Derived terms

[edit]
  • cognac

Translations

[edit]
city
  • Arabic: كُونْيَاك (kūnyāk)
  • Bulgarian: Коня́к m (Konják)
  • Catalan: Cognac m, Conyac m
  • Chinese:
    Cantonese: 干邑 (gon1 jap1)
    Mandarin: 科尼亞克 / 科尼亚克 (Kēníyàkè), 干邑 (zh) (gānyì)
  • Dutch: Cognac n
  • French: Cognac (fr) m
  • Greek: Κονιάκ (el) (Koniák)
  • Japanese: コニャック (ja) (Konyakku)
  • Korean: 코냐크 (Konyakeu)
  • Occitan: Conhac m
  • Poitevin-Saintongeais: Cougnat m
  • Polish: Cognac (pl) m
  • Ukrainian: Коньяк (Konʹjak)

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Medieval Latin Comniacum, from the name Cominius + Gallo-Roman suffix -acum, from Proto-Celtic *-ākom. The gens Cominius is an Italic family name; see Cominia for further details.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /kɔ.ɲak/
  • Audio (Paris):(file)
  • Audio:(file)

Proper noun

[edit]

Cognac m

  1. Cognac (a city and commune of Charente department, region of Nouvelle-Aquitaine, France; famous for cognac brandy)

Derived terms

[edit]
  • Cognaçais
  • cognaçais
  • cognac

German

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)

Noun

[edit]

Cognac m (strong, genitive Cognacs, plural Cognacs)

  1. alternative form of Kognak

Declension

[edit]
Declension of Cognac [masculine, strong]
singular plural
indef. def. noun def. noun
nominative ein der Cognac die Cognacs
genitive eines des Cognacs der Cognacs
dative einem dem Cognac den Cognacs
accusative einen den Cognac die Cognacs
